docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. MICHAEL J. OTTEN Teamwork and Tradition On the job, Michael J. Otten was a dedicated, third-generation firefighter. He joined Ladder Company 35, near Lincoln Center, when he was 26, and spent nearly 16 years there.

headline.main: Team Player, Sailor at Heart, Loving Sibling, Thoughtful Organizer

byline.original: These sketches were written by Anthony DePalma, Aaron Donovan, Robin Finn, Constance L. Hays, Jan Hoffman, Tina Kelley and Michelle O'Donnell

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has shown that a simple and inexpensive drug given just once after birth can protect many infants from infection with the virus that causes AIDS, South African researchers reported at the 14th International AIDS Conference that ended here on Friday. In the study, babies who were given a single dose of the AIDS drug nevirapine within 24 hours after birth were no more likely to become infected with H.I.V. than those given another drug, AZT, for the first six weeks of life.

headline.main: Cheaper Drug Prevents H.I.V. In Newborns, Study Shows

docs.lead_paragraph: Margaret Talbot's article was indeed timely (The Way We Live Now, June 30). Just last week, the Senate Finance Committee passed a welfare-reform bill that continues $50 million annually in federal financing for ''abstinence only until marriage'' programs. Most Americans prefer an approach that includes both abstinence and information about other methods to prevent pregnancy and sexually transmitted disease. Leslie M. Kantor The Othmer Institute Planned Parenthood of New York City New York
docs.abstract: Planned Parenthood of New York City official Leslie M Kantor letter on Margaret Talbot's June 30 article contends most Americans want sex education programs that teach abstinence as well as other methods of preventing pregnancy

docs.lead_paragraph: ON the season finale of NBC's ''Friends,'' the unhappily single Rachel -- whose accidental pregnancy was revealed at the close of the previous season -- finally gave birth to a baby daughter. Now, as Rachel's belly expands again in reruns, you can't help wondering: how badly is this baby going to wreck the show? Not to put too much pressure on the ''Friends'' writers, but has any show ever gotten better after the birth of its season-ending bundle of joy? Here's some advice for any television writer itching to get into bed with the old cliffhanger-pregnancy plot line: think back to your high school sex-education class, especially the part where you had to carry around an egg for a week to simulate the inescapable responsibilities of parenthood. A series shouldn't have a sweeps baby unless it's ready for that baby to be there for the next 22 (or 44 or 66) episodes. And don't expect a sweeps baby to save a failing series, either. Did ''The X-Files'' regain its luster after Scully had her miracle baby? Did ''Mad About You'' finally get funny after the Buchmans conceived? And yet, the babies keep coming.

headline.main: The Sweeps Baby: An Argument for Abstinence

docs.abstract: Joyce Millman article, recalling previous television shows with cliffhanger-pregnancy plot lines, questions whether Friends will be wrecked by birth of Rachel's baby; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Teen Health Book: A Parents' Guide to Adolescent Health and Well-Being,'' Dr. Ralph I. Lopez, W. W. Norton & Company, $26.95 Dr. Lopez began working in his specialty in the early 1970's when it was still fairly new, and when American teenagers were winning little sympathy from adults.
